This
On
Week
List
Fiction
THE VILLA, by Nora Roberts. (Jove, $7.99.) A successful businesswoman is torn between her professional rivalry with a vintner and her strong attraction to him.
DUST TO DUST, by Tami Hoag. (Bantam, $7.99.) Two Minneapolis police officers investigate the suspicious death of an Internal Affairs cop.
ON THE STREET WHERE YOU LIVE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Pocket Books, $7.99.) A defense lawyer finds herself haunted by two murders that took place 110 years apart.
A PAINTED HOUSE, by John Grisham. (Dell, $7.99.) The experiences of a 7-year-old boy whose parents live and work in the cotton fields of Arkansas.
FALL ON YOUR KNEES, by Ann-Marie MacDonald. (Scribner Paperback Fiction, $14.) The story of a family on Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia.
1ST TO DIE, by James Patterson. (Warner Vision, $7.99.) Four women -- a homicide inspector, a medical examiner, an assistant D.A. and a journalist -- search for a killer who is stalking newlyweds.
ON A WILD NIGHT, by Stephanie Laurens. (Avon, $7.50.) A refined 19th-century Englishwoman ventures into the forbidden part of London's night life.
FINAL TARGET, by Iris Johansen. (Bantam, $7.50.) After seeing her nanny and Secret Service agents killed, the president's daughter becomes catatonic.

THE LONER, by Joan Johnston. (Dell, $6.99.) A Texas woman discovers that the powerful man she believed to be her father is instead the father of her former lover, who comes home for a final reckoning.
SLIGHTLY SHADy, by Amanda Quick. (Bantam, $7.50.) An enterprising Englishwoman forms an alliance with a mysterious spy.
REUNION IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Berkley, $7.99.) Lt. Eve Dallas of the New York Police Department must contend with an evil woman she helped send to prison years earlier.
KENTUCKY RICH, by Fern Michaels. (Zebra, $7.99.) When a woman returns to her family's thoroughbred horse farm after 30 years, unsettling truths emerge.
DEATH IN HOLY ORDERS, by P. D. James. (Ballantine, $7.99.) Cmdr. Adam Dalgliesh looks into the death of a powerful businessman's son at a small theological college in England.
COLD PARADISE, by Stuart Woods. (Signet, $7.99.) The lawyer-investigator Stone Barrington travels to Palm Beach to help a beautiful, enigmatic woman.
SCARLET FEATHER, by Maeve Binchy. (Signet, $7.99.) Tom Feather and Cathy Scarlet, friends from cooking school, start a catering company in Dublin.

On
Week
List
Nonfiction
A BEAUTIFUL MIND, by Sylvia Nasar. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $16.) A biography of John Nash, the mathematical genius who suffered from schizophrenia and eventually won a Nobel Prize.
WE WERE SOLDIERS ONCE . . . AND YOUNG, by Harold G. Moore and Joseph L. Galloway. (Perennial, $16; HarperTorch, $7.99.) Vietnam as experienced by two battalions during a battle in 1965.
SEABISCUIT, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Ballantine, $15.) A biography of the horse whose career culminated in a 1938 match race with War Admiral.
A CHILD CALLED ''IT,'' by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $9.95.) The autobiography of a man who survived his mother's abuse. (+)
BLACK HAWK DOWN, by Mark Bowden. (Penguin, $13.95; Signet, $7.99.) The bloody battle between American forces and Somali street fighters in 1993.
FAST FOOD NATION, by Eric Schlosser. (Peren-nial/HarperCollins, $13.95.) A survey of ''the dark side of the all-American meal.''
*FOUNDING BROTHERS, by Joseph J. Ellis. (Vintage, $14.) A historian's study of the intertwined lives of the nation's founders.
THE O'REILLY FACTOR, by Bill O'Reilly. (Broadway, $14.) The host of a cable news program offers opinions on what's right and wrong with America.
KILLING PABLO, by Mark Bowden. (Penguin, $14.) The rise and fall of Pablo Escobar, head of the Medell√≠n drug cartel until his death in 1993.
THE LOST BOY, by Dave Pelzer. (Health Communications, $10.95.) The author of ''A Child Called 'It' '' recalls his life in foster homes. (+)
NAPALM & SILLY PUTTY, by George Carlin. (Hyperion, $12.95.) The comedian offers opinions on everything from God to pets to the Lone Ranger.
ME TALK PRETTY ONE DAY, by David Sedaris. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $14.95.) Autobiographical comic essays by the author of ''Naked.''
THE FIRST AMERICAN, by H. W. Brands. (Anchor, $17.) A biography of Benjamin Franklin (1706-90).
THE NOONDAY DEMON, by Andrew Solomon. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $16.) A personal, cultural and scientific survey of depression.
THE PIANO SHOP ON THE LEFT BANK, by Thad Carhart. (Random House, $13.95.) An American expatriate in Paris rediscovers his love of music.
*WALKING THE BIBLE, by Bruce Feiler. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $14.95.) A 10,000-mile journey retracing the story told in the Pentateuch.

Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Hardcover
SELF MATTERS, by Phillip C. McGraw. (Simon & Schuster Source, $25.) How to reclaim one's authentic identity. (+)
THE HEALTHY KITCHEN, by Andrew Weil and Rosie Daley. (Knopf, $24.95.) A cookbook devoted to good nutrition.
THE WISDOM OF MENOPAUSE, by Christiane Northrup. (Bantam, $27.95.) The ways in which menopause offers opportunities for renewal.
BODY FOR LIFE, by Bill Phillips with Michael D'Orso. (HarperCollins, $26.) Ways to improve one's body and one's life. (+)
THE PRAYER OF JABEZ FOR WOMEN, by Darlene Wilkinson. (Multnomah, $9.99.) Counsel on ''breaking through to the blessed life.'' (+)

Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous: Paperback
DR. ATKINS' NEW DIET REVOLUTION, by Robert C. Atkins. (Avon, $14 and $7.99.) Ways to lose weight and achieve a healthy body. (+)
THE WRINKLE CURE, by Nicholas Perricone. (Warner, $13.95.) A dermatologist's anti-aging program.
RICH DAD, POOR DAD, by Robert T. Kiyosaki with Sharon L. Lechter. (Warner, $15.95.) Teaching one's children how to get rich and stay rich.
THE FOUR AGREEMENTS, by Don Miguel Ruiz. (Amber-Allen, $12.95.) A code of conduct based on personal freedom. (+)
LIFE STRATEGIES, by Phillip C. McGraw. (Hyperion, $11.95.) Advice on how to find what matters in your life and what to do about it. (+)

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended April 6, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 60,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
